questions.text: Which among the following is a cardinal sign of inflammation?
Which of the following features is a characteristic of acute inflammation?

options.label: C
options.text: The predominance of lymphocytes in the inflammatory infiltrate

options.label: D
options.text: Accumulation of neutrophils at the site of injury

questions.correct_answer: D. Accumulation of neutrophils at the site of injury
questions.explanation:
Acute Inflammation

Chronic Inflammation

Causative agent

Pathogen, injured tissues

Persistent acute inflammation due to non degradable pathogens, persistent foreign bodies, or autoimmune reactions

Cells infiltrated

Neutrophils/Polymorphonuclear cells (PMN).

 

Exception: Typhoid (Relative Lymphocytosis)

Lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells

 

Exception: Chronic

Pseudomonas (it shows persistence of Neutrophils)

Primary mediators

Vasoactive amines, eicosanoids

IFN-y and other cytokines, growth factors, reactive oxygen species, hydrolytic enzymes

Onset

Immediate

Delayed

Duration

 

Few days

Up to many months or years

Outcomes

 

Resolution , abscess formation, chronic inflammation

Tissue destruction, fibrosis

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms primarily contributed to the increased vascular permeability in this patient's with a right knee injury after fall from stairs?

options.label: A
options.text: Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in the opening of interendothelial gaps

questions.correct_answer: A. Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in the opening of interendothelial gaps

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the hallmark event of acute inflammation?
questions.explanation:
Vascular events -> Cellular events
  1. Transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Vasodilation.
  3. Increased vascular permeability.
  4. Stasis.
  1. Margination.
  2. Rolling.
  3. Adhesion.
  4. Transmigration.
  5. Chemotaxis.
  6. Opsonization.
  7. Phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by recurrent catalase positive bacterial, and fungal infections, defective nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test results, and deficient reactive oxygen species production by phagocytes?
Which of the following defects is most likely associated with Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency Type 1 (LAD)-1?

options.label: B
options.text: Defective synthesis of Sialyl Lewis X modified glycoprotein

questions.correct_answer: A. Defective synthesis of β2 integrin
questions.explanation:
LAD-1

LAD-2

LAD-3

Defective synthesis of β2 chain of CD11/CD18 integrins (β2 integrin).

(Option A)

Defective synthesis of sialyl-Lewis X modified glycoprotein, a ligand for E- and P-selectins.

(Option B)

Mutations in the FERMT3 genes.

(Option C)

Clinical manifestations include delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump in newborns, and recurrent bacterial infections.

Clinically, LAD 2 patients may exhibit a Bombay Blood group phenotype.

Clinical presentation is similar to LAD-1, along with bleeding disorders due to platelet dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about granulomas is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Granuloma formation is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction

options.label: B
options.text: IFN gamma is an important cytokine involved in the process

options.label: C
options.text: CD8+ is the type of T lymphocytes involved in this process

options.label: D
options.text: Epitheloid cells in granuloma are modified macrophages

questions.correct_answer: C. CD8+ is the type of T lymphocytes involved in this process

questions.text: Which of the following cell types is classified as stable cells in terms of their proliferative capacity and turnover rate?

options.label: C
options.text: Stratified squamous epithelia of the skin

questions.correct_answer: D. Endothelial cells in blood vessels
questions.explanation:
Labile cells

Stable cells

Permanent cells
  • These cells are continuously being lost and replaced by maturation from tissue stem cells and by the proliferation of mature cells.
  • Labile cells include hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow (Option B) and the majority of surface epithelia (Option C)

 
  • They are quiescent and have minimal proliferative activity from progenitor cells.
  • They divide only when required but limited regeneration compared to labile cells.
  • Stable cells constitute the parenchyma of most solid tissues(liver), endothelial cells (Option D), fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells.
  
  • These cells are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life.
  • Permanent cells include Neurons (Option A) and cardiac and skeletal muscle cells.

questions.text: Which type of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) is involved in microbial killing and is induced in macrophages by cytokines or microbial products?
questions.explanation:
Type

Constitutive Expression

Function

Endothelial (eNOS)

Low levels

Maintains vascular tone

Neuronal (nNOS)

Low levels

Functions as a neurotransmitter

Inducible (iNOS)

Induced in macrophages(not constitutive expression)

Involved in microbial killing, induced by cytokines or microbial products

questions.text: Which of the following is the role of neutrophil lysosomal enzymes in acute inflammation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cleavage of C3 and C5
questions.explanation:
Azurophil (primary) granules

Specific (secondary) granules
  1. Myeloperoxidase (MPO)
  2. Defensins
  3. Acid hydrolases
  4. Neutral proteases
  5. Elastase
  6. Cathepsin G
  7. Nonspecific collagenases
  8. Proteinase 3
  9. Lysozyme
  1. Lysozyme
  2. Collagenase
  3. Gelatinase
  4. Lactoferrin
  5. Plasminogen activator
  6. Histaminase

 

Enzyme

Function

Enzyme

Function

Myeloperoxidase

Generates reactive oxygen species for microbial killing

Proteinase 3

Degrades proteins in phagolysosomes

Defensins

Disrupts microbial cell membranes

Lysozyme

Degrades bacterial cell walls

Acid hydrolases

Degrades bacteria and debris in phagolysosomes

Collagenase

Degrades collagen in extracellular matrix

Neutral proteases

Degrades extracellular matrix components, cleaves complement proteins

Gelatinase

Degrades gelatin in extracellular matrix

Elastase

Degrades elastin combats bacterial infections

Lactoferrin

Binds and sequesters iron due to defects in the alternate pathway.

Cathepsin G

Degrades proteins in phagolysosomes

Plasminogen activator

Converts plasminogen to plasmin, fibrinolysis

Nonspecific collagenases

Degrades collagen in extracellular matrix

Histaminase

Metabolizes histamine and limits inflammatory response.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of PAF in inducing bronchoconstriction?

options.label: A
options.text: By binding to seven transmembrane G protein–coupled receptors.

options.label: B
options.text: Causing smooth muscle constriction by directly stimulating muscarinic receptors

options.label: C
options.text: Induction of smooth muscle relaxation and bronchodilation

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of platelets and leukocytes leading to release of inflammatory mediators

questions.correct_answer: D. Activation of platelets and leukocytes leading to release of inflammatory mediators

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. Which of the following chemokines is primarily responsible for recruiting neutrophils to the airways in COPD exacerbations?
Which of the following is false regarding the alternate complement pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: Teichoic acid is an initiator of the alternate complement pathway.

options.label: B
options.text: The first complement protein to be activated is C1.

options.label: C
options.text: The C3 convertase of the alternate pathway is C3bBb.

options.label: D
options.text: Properdin deficiency involves the alternate pathway.

questions.correct_answer: B. The first complement protein to be activated is C1.
questions.explanation:
Pathogens from microbes

Non-microbial initiators
  • Gram (-ve) bacteria: Endotoxins or lipopolysaccharides.
  • Gram (+ve) bacteria: Teichoic acid. (Option A)
  • Fungal cells: Yeast cells.
  • Parasites: Trypanosoma.
  • Virus-infected cells.
  • Human antibodies in complexes: IgA, IgD.
  • Tumor cells.
  • Cobra venom factor.
  • Heterologous RBCs from mice, rabbits, and chickens.
  • Anion polymer like dextran sulfate.
  • Pure carbohydrates like agar and inulin.

Features

Classical

Alternate

Lectin

Activator (initiator)

Antigen-antibody complex

Endotoxin, IgA, IgD etc

Carbohydrate

residue of the bacterial cell wall (mannose-binding protein) that binds to the host lectin antigen

1st complement to be activated

C1

C3 (Option B)

C4

C3 convertase

C14b2a

C3bBb (Option C)

MBL/MASP-C4b2a

C5 convertase (C3 convertase + 3b)

C14b2a3b

C3bBb3b

MBL/MASP-C4b2a3b

Complement levels in the serum

All C1-C9: Low

C1, C2, C4: Normal

Others: Low

C1: Normal

Others: Low

Immunity

Acquired

Innate

Innate

questions.text: Pain during inflammation is mediated by?
questions.explanation:
(Serotonin)

(Option A)
  • Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT), is a neurotransmitter and vasoactive substance produced primarily by enterochromaffin cells in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It regulates mood, appetite, and sleep, as well as gastrointestinal motility and platelet aggregation.
  • In the context of inflammation, serotonin released from platelets and mast cells can contribute to vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • Its role in inflammation is less prominent compared to other mediators like histamine and bradykinin.

(Leukotrienes)

(Option B)
  • Leukotrienes are lipid mediators synthesized from arachidonic acid metabolism, primarily by the 5-lipoxygenase pathway.
  • They play a significant role in the pathogenesis of asthma and allergic reactions by inducing bronchoconstriction, increasing vascular permeability, and promoting the recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of inflammation.

(Interleukin-1)

(Option C)
  • Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a proinflammatory cytokine produced by various cells, including macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells, in response to infection, injury, or inflammation.
  • It plays a central role in the inflammatory response by inducing fever, activating immune cells, and promoting the production of other cytokines and inflammatory mediators.
  • However, IL-1 is not a primary mediator responsible for the localized symptoms described in the clinical scenario, including pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth following a traumatic injury.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding wound healing is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The wound regains 20% of its normal strength by 1 week.

options.label: B
options.text: The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.

options.label: C
options.text: The wound regains its original strength eventually.

options.label: D
options.text: The initial collagen formed in the process of wound healing is Type-1 collagen.

questions.correct_answer: B. The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.
